noun.description: Belief in or acceptance of something as true.
examples: psychoanalysis finds little credence among laymen

noun.description: A small side table, shelf, or niche in a church for holding the elements of the Eucharist before they are consecrated.

phrases: These are recipes that experts give credence to and experiments show work.
So it's bad when reporters get it wrong, but it's worse when officials give credence to these stories and speak of them as if they know their facts.
He was most surprised that it would attack another dog but had to give credence to what had been said.
History provides enough evidence to give credence to what I have said.
They masquerade under the illusion that all is well, when in fact they give credence to paranoia and anxiety.
origin: Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin credentia, from Latin credent- believing, from the verb credere.
